ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend this to a student who wants to learn very specifically about ethnic conflict and take a very well-taught, traditional Political Science class.

I would recommend this class if you're interested in ethnic conflict! It's interesting with interesting discussion but it's almost two hours long which can get a bit dull at times. We do study a bit of history but mostly focus on theories.

Take this if you want to study ethnic conflict from the political science and statistical perspective. You learn a lot about how modeling tracks ethnic conflicts. It's a good balance for less scientific political science courses on conflict.

Yes, I definitely recommend this course to someone interested in conflicts or international affairs in general. This course is a great way to delve deep into an issue and study the various academic answers to an important question. Professor Sambanis is very knowledgeable, and there is a lot to learn from the class.

Awesome class with a really great, knowledgeable professor. Sambanis is wonderful as both scholar and lecturer, though not as strong as a seminar facilitator. Watch the group you get -- we had a few very strong, dominant personalities that ended up taking the class over, at times. If you're at all interested in cycles of violence / ethnic civil wars / nation-building and post-conflict institution, take this class!
